div.head:
Embleme 21. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Make offor the man and the woman a circle, of that a quadrangle, of this
a triangle, of the Same a circle, and you will have the Philosoph. Stone.

lg.l: A circle for the man and wife provide,
Which make quadrangular with æquallequal side,
That trigonalltrigonal, resulting in a Sphere:
And then the blessed Stone to you'leyou'll appear.
If this too high and too abstruse you find,
Geometry will soon informe your mind.

div.head: Discourse 21.
div.ab:
It is the doctrine of that most famous Philosopher Plato that knowledge is as
it were actually engraven and imprinted in the mind of man, which is as the
foundation of all arts and Sciences, by the remembrance and repetition of-
which all learning may be knowne and apprehended by any man; which-
to prove, hee introducethintroduces a youth yet very young, ignorant, and illiterate,-
whome hee instructed first in geometricall interrogations soe, that the
youth was observed to answer directly to all quæstions, and nolens volens, or
without consideration to have attaindattained to the very marrow of soe intricate
a Science: From whence hee concludes that noe doctrine and discipline is-
learned or understood at the first, but onely by remembrance and repeti
tion recalled and revolved into the mind by children, alluding to his An
nus magnus, wherein before the solary of 48 thousand yeares the same
persons, things and actions were sayd by him to have been before the re
volution of the heaven, after the same manner, as now: But these things-
every man understands are like dreams without any foundation of truth:
That there are some certaine sparks of knowledge naturally radicated in
us, and mere powers, to be reduced into action by use and instruction, wee
doe not deny, but wee deny that they are soe great and of such quality,
as to be the seminaryesseminaries of arts and sciences without any præcedentprecedent-
præparation: From whence therefore came Sciences and arts, if men in
vented them not, others may aske the quæstion, whether they were first
taught by heaven, or by the Gods of the heaven? I answer, it is one-
thing to say, that burning coalescoals are covered under ashes in soe great plenty,
that if they may onely appear by removing the ashes, they are sufficient
to boyle meat, or warme our cold limbs; it is another thing to affirme, that
small sparks onely doe there lyelie hid, which, before they can be usefulluseful-
for boyling or warming, must by the industry, art, and care of man be
stirrdbestirred up, quickened, and nourishdnourished with fuellfuel, otherwise they may easily
be extinguished, and wholy reduced into cold ashes: The last is the asser
tion of the Aristotelians, the first of the Platonists: With the last agrees
reason and experience, with the first onely phantasyfantasy or imagination: Where
upon it might be demanded, why Plato wrote upon the dooredoor of his SchooleSchool,
that hee that was ignorant of Geometry Should not be admitted into it, hee
